title: bbc public broadcaster pays megabucks
story: Anyone who realised that the organisation for which they work is awash with cash would do the same.When Ahmed realised that she was receiving only £ for presenting her -minute long BBC programme when Jeremy Vine was being paid £, for his show of the same , she thought, not unreasonably, “I want a bit of that”.Like any other employee, she has every right to use the employment tribunal system to settle grievances. Yet the way Ahmed’s case has been pumped up as a great cause celebre for women is frankly ridiculous.The real scandal is not that a highly paid female BBC presenter has been paid less than a male one. It is that the BBC is lavishing such fat pay on any of them while pleading poverty and ending free TV licences for people over .Ahmed’s case for equal pay is very weak. It is based on the argument that presenting Newswatch — which holds BBC’s news programmes to account — is of equal value to presenting Vine’s old show, Points Of View, which invited comments from the public on a wide iety of BBC programmes.The BBC claims the disparity is down to the fact that Points Of View is classied as entertainment while Newswatch comes under news.  Surely a more direct comparison would be between what Ahmed is paid and what her male predecessor, Raymond Snoddy, was paid.She received the same as he did. How is that gender discrimination   But while the BBC might have a strong defence in Ahmed’s case, it doesn’t endear the corporation to me.Every time the BBC Charter comes up for renewal, it poses as a terribly worthy public ­service broadcaster putting out serious, educational programmes no commercial broadcaster would touch.Unless the Government allows it to jack up the licence fee, it argues, it will mean no more David Attenborough, no more news correspondents in Mogadishu.Then, as soon as the BBC Charter is renewed, it goes back to pumping out the same old entertainment shows, many of them indistinguishable from commercial TV.A genuine public service broadcaster would not pay Gary Lineker £.million a year, Graham Norton £,or Huw Edwards £,.Compared with the fattest of BBC fat cats, Samira Ahmed might well feel undervalued. Yet earning £ for presenting a -minute programme would be a dream for many TV licence-payers, many of whom do not even earn that amount of money in a week.The BBC is merciless in its efforts to collect what is really a tax on TV ownership. Unlike other unpaid utility bills, failing to buy a TV licence is a criminal offence, leading to low-paid people struggling with finances being dragged through the courts.Last year, , people were prosecuted for non-payment. By the way,  per cent of them were women — possibly because they were more likely to be at home during the day when TV licence enforcement officers tend to call. That is the real gender unfairness, not highly paid female BBC presenters receiving less money than male presenters.Ahmed’s case has highlighted the old boys’ world from which the BBC hires its presenters.  Vine, she claims, was “gted” his Radio  show without any proper recruitment process. BBC management then allowed his agent to jack up his salary.The BBC seems to see itself as immune from the pay restraint where in the public sector. When David Cameron became Prime Minister, he said any public body would need an extremely good excuse to pay anyone more than the £, a year he then earned.Yet the BBC’s accounts for   show it paid  “on-air talent” salaries in excess of this figure.  While there have been token reductions for some male ­presenters, such as the now- retired John Humphrys, many have seen salary increases.High pay doesn’t end with the presenters. There were also  BBC managers and executives who were paid more than the PM last year.  If the BBC wants to justy the TV licence, it needs to be cutting excessive pay among its board and ­presenters.If it wants to be a commercial station, on the other hand, it should give up the licence fee and find funding from subscriptions and ­advertising.  Then it wouldn’t be our business how much its executives and presenters were paid because their salaries would come out of the pockets only of people who chose to subscribe to its programmes.This is particularly important now, in the week that both Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn have vowed to sort out the threat of over-s losing their licence fee exemption.As it becomes an urgent election issue, the worst look for the BBC is to be seen throwing money at presenters rather than the people it needs most — its loyal viewers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lottery winners set for life cat
story: Sylvia Odolant-Smith, , matched all five main numbers and the Le Ball in the Set for Le draw - despite calling herself the National Lotterys unluckiest player.The -year-old, from Battersea, South London, is now looking forward to a bumper paycheck of £, every month for the next  years with husband Gavin, .And they are already planning to use some of the cash to pay for expensive veterinary treatment for their poorly rescue cat Phangan.Sylvia said: Earlier in the week we were advised one of our rescue cats, Phangan, needed an expensive veterinary treatment which was going to put a serious dent in our savings.Within seconds of the win being confirmed, Phangan’s vet appointment was too.”Sylvia was checking her emails before work as a catering manager when she saw she had received one from Lotto chiefs about a win.She at first thought shed won just £ - but was stunned to see she had actually scooped the le-changing sum of money.Sylvia said: I always used to daydream thatI won the lottery I’d plan a really special way to share the news with Gavin. Waking him up at .am waving my phone in his face screeching ‘look at this, look at this’ definitely wasn’t it!While sharing the news with Gavin that morning wasn’t quite as I envisaged, making the call was much better.We met at a pub in Oxford Circus, ordered a bottle of Champagne, sat down and made the call to Camelot.”The couple have a Set For Le list to figure out how to spend the rest of their winnings - including trips abroad, helping out friends and family and giving money to charity.They will also treat their nieces to a trip to Disneyland and Gavin wants to start taking French lessons.But they are not planning to give up their jobs - despite working gruelling  hour weeks in the catering industry.Sylvia said: Ultimately, our long-term plan is to have a business in France. I’m from there originally and we can’t think of a better place for us to enjoy being Set For Le.When we make that move, there will be more time and maybe then I will be able to explore making my interior design hobby and sustainable living ethos into a business.The jackpot is an annuity-style prize — a guaranteed fat salary of £, every month for  years.While the way the top prize is paid out is new to National Lottery players, the way to play Set For Le is straightforward.You pick five main numbers from  to , and one ‘Le Ball’ from  to , for the chance to win fixed prizes – with everything from the top prize of £, a month for  years*, to the nd prize of £, a month for one year*you get all the main numbers and not the ‘Le Ball’, to £ for matching just two main numbers.If a winner passes away before receiving their entire prize money, it will go to their estate according to their will.*Subject to prize capping - more information about prize capping will be available in the Set For Le Games Procedures.Sylvia bought the winning Lucky Dip ticket for the draw on October  - becoming the ninth top winner in the game.Another player won £, a month for a year, while  people got a one-off sum of £.Set for Le was launched on March  this year by Camelot to give Brits the chance to win a fat salary each month.The mum-of-two said the prize was still sinking in, but was already planning a string of city breaks, starting in Budapest.She also said she would buy a house with a bigger garden for her son to play football in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum baby boy river irwell gives birth
story: Zakari William Bennett-Eko, who was  months old, was thrown into the River Irwell in Radclfe, Greater Manchester, in a Moses basket, it is claimed.His dad Zak Eko, , has been charged with murder after the tot passed away in hospital on September .His mum Emma Blood, who said her le had changed forever after the tragedy, has now given birth to a baby girl called Isla, the Mirror reports.The -year-old wrote in a touching Facebook post last week: I am proud of many things in le but nothing beats being a mother.Emma, who was praised by a friend commenting on the photo as an amazing mum has also updated her Facebook bio to read Zakari and Isla with blue and pink heart emojis.Emma had made a series of heartbreaking tributes to little Zakari after he tragically passed away.She said: I woke up that morning being a mummy to the most wonderful cute little boy and by the afternoon Zakari was taken from me in the most tragic of circumstances.Zakari was my le for  months and will be the heart of our family for many years to come.He was a cheeky little chappie with a smile that melted hearts. title: castle transformation home wales
story: It took Anton Jones  years to buy what was known locally as Llantwit Castle from the Vale of Glamorgan council and another five years to transform the medieval house.No cranes or cement mixers were used and all the materials were mixed and constructed using traditional methods.Lime mortar was used and the solid oak beams were cut and constructed on site.Anton was fascinated with the building since he was a child where he used to play but was also “scared to death of it.”He said: It was very, very creepy in those days because the ruin was totally covered in ivy.It was always very gloomy even on a summers day and there was always an eerie presence here and I actually got chased by horses here once.I can still hear the hooves hitting the stones now when Im working here.”When he bought the property for £, the “conservation builder” feared he had bitten off more than he could chew when the extent of the restoration project became fully clear.Anton said: It was completely ruined, in fact it shouldnt really have been saved because it was too far gone.At least five metres off the top of the walls had to be taken down simply because it has been open to the elements for over  years. Yes, it hasnt had a roof for over  years.A huge maze of scaffolding needed to be erected, including over the top of the ruin, to at long last get the site watertight and ready for the biggest renovation Anton has ever tackled.He remembers: All the stone dressings were found buried in the floor in pieces, so we dug those up and put them all back together like a massive jigsaw piece.Hundreds of tons of stone needed to be lted in the air and we did it all with block and tackle which is the original lting mechanism just the two of us, we did it all by hand.But the hard work eventually paid off with the listed property having a “special atmosphere”.Anton says: Its a lovely atmosphere here, most people can feel it, its a special thing. Its church like and very peaceful however its got a very welcoming atmosphere.And what is special and unique about it is that theres still this ruinous part attached to the home.I think to restore the remaining ruin would actually ruin it. Its what makes the house so romantic.Instead of no roof, no floors and barely any walls, it now has three storeys of rooms that ooze authentic medieval character but with modern amenities.The Old Castle is for sale for £.m with estate agent Brinsons  Birt.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn does an ed miliband
story: The Labour boss has told voters his government will fulfil  central pledgesthey get to No – reminiscent of his predecessors hapless “Ed Stone” stunt.Mr Corbyn told supporters in Shropshire, his home county, this morning: I want a Labour government to be judged by whether it changes people’s lives for the better after five years.Judge us on the real change we deliver the concrete improvements to the lives of millions of people.These include vows to abolish in-work poverty, stop food bank use and tackle the country’s social care crisis within five years of reaching Downing Street.that he was “not born to rule” and has pledged to “share” his powerhe wins the election and “open a door for others to walk through.He said: “The politics I stand for is about sharing power and wealth with people who don’t have a lot of money, don’t have friends in high places, so they can take control of their own lives.”The leftie boss added that it offers a chance to rebuild the NHS, schools and police force – by “taxing those at the top to properly fund the services for everyone .”Mr Corbyn also slammed the Tories for comments Jacob Rees-Mogg made about after victims of the Grenfell Tower blaze lacking Common sense for failing to leave.He said: They shamefully seem to think the victims of the Grenfell fire died because they didn’t have the common sense to save themselves.I’ll tell you what’s common sense:Don’t put flammable cladding on people’s homes. That’s common sense.Don’t close fire stations and dont cut fire fighters. That’s common sense.And don’t ignore residents when they tell you their home is a death trap.But the Mr Corbyns commandments have been slammed by Tories as “not worth the paper they’re written on”.Tory Chairman James Cleverly said Mr Corbyn’s “track record” over Brexit “very few people will believe a word he says.”David Morris, Tory candidate for Morecambe and Lunesdale, likened Mr Corbyn’s pledges to those written on the Ed Stone, hauled out by the former hapless Labour boss in .He said: “While Mr Corbyn may not have committed these to stone, just like his predecessor no one will believe a word he says given his record of broken promises.”The Ed Stone tablet showed six promises – meant to highlight Labour’s commitment to deliver on manesto pledges compared to the Liberal Democrats.Mr Miliband pledged to erect the stone in the Downing Street rose gardenhe got to No.However, after a disastrous election campaign saw him defeated by David Cameron - the stone mysteriously disappeared.Mr Corbyn’s key speech today comes after his Brexit stance was rubbished as a “fairytale”.Tory No Deal minister Michael Gove said: It is a fairytaleyou imagine Jeremy Corbyn can get Brexit done.“His policy on Brexit has been constructed by a terminally weak leader in order to paper over the cracks in his party.More than half of Brits are confused about Labour’s Brexit stance – despite Mr Corbyn claiming it “isn’t complicated”.Sixty five per cent of people are unclear, while only  per cent of voters believe Mr Corbyn is clear about his position, according to a YouGov poll.Mr Corbyn will then put both options back to the public with a second referendum – but has yet to say how the party would campaign.

title: remainer parties lib dems greens and plaid form pact
story: Leaders of the parties will not run candidates against each other in  seats and have labelled their new union the Unite To Remain group.The deal follows a similar Remainer pact made earlier this year in the Brecon and Radnorshire by-election, where the Lib Dems took the seat from the Tories after two other parties stepped aside.Heidi Allen, chairwoman of Unite To Remain, said the cross-party arrangement is unprecedented in modern British political history.In the Isle of Wight and Brighton Pavilion, the Greens will be given a free run, while in the constituencies of Richmond Park and Cheltenham, the Lib Dems will be unopposed by other Remain-backing parties.Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson said she is delighted an agreement has been reached, adding that it is a signicant moment for all people who want to support remain candidates across the country.Ms Allen, ex Lib Dem MP for South Cambridgeshire, said: This is a Brexit election, and staying in the European Union is possible - and this is the deciding moment.We are putting party politics aside in the interest of our country and have cemented a cross-party arrangement whereby Remain-voting parties in England and Wales are working together to back one Remain candidate.With a single Remain candidate in each of these seats we can deliver a greater number of MPs into Parliament.“This is our opportunity to tip the balance of power away from the two largest parties and into a progressive Remain Alliance.The number of seats achieved, and the scope of what were seeking to achieve, is unprecedented in modern British political history. Together, we can unite to Remain.Adam Price, leader of Plaid Cymru, said: In these deeply serious times we need grown-up politics that puts our countries before parties.The single most important thing in this election is that weas many pro-Remain MPs back in Parliament as possible.Sian Berry, co-leader of the Green Party, said: The crash-out Brexit the Tories are pushing for would be a disaster for people up and down England and Wales. And for action on climate chaos.Ms Allen, who will not be standing in the General Election, told BBC Radio s Today programme that the sense of a common purpose really focused minds.Further details will be announced at a press conference on Thursday morning.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson finally launched his election campaign today - and it looks like he started as he means to go on.The Prime Minister blurted out an avalanche of half truths, deceptions and flat out lies as he told voters to “come with us” on BrexitStanding in front of the black door of  Downing Street, he spoke in his first event after meeting the Queen following the dissolution of Parliament. He was in full political mode, denouncing Corbyn as a friend of Russia and boasting of advances under the Tories. Yet from hospitals to immigration his hardline attacks just don’t ring true - or left key details out. And he even got the number of days he’s been in office wrong. Here are the  biggest lies and deceptions he told on the first day of the campaign. WHAT HE SAID: It has been frankly mind-boggling in the last few weeks to see how parliament first voted to approve this deal, and then voted for delay. THE FACTS: Parliament did not vote to approve the PM’s Brexit deal. Instead it backed the second reading of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill. Despite its name, second reading is basically the first hurdle a Bill goes through on the long road to becoming law. Often MPs back a Bill at second reading to secure a debate, but then vote against at a later pointit isnapost amended to be acceptable - and several said they would have done so in this case.   . Heaposs building  new hospitalsWHAT HE SAID:  new hospitals. THE FACTS: Boris Johnson ’s promise of  ‘new hospitals’ will actually only deliver six unless the Tories win the next two elections - not one future election, but two. And it includes renovations of existing hospitals.WHAT HE SAID: Go with Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party, because thataposs the only alternative, who actually want to ban OFSTED, that protects kids from bullying. THE FACTS: Labour would scrap Ofsted - but in what you might think is a key detail, it would be replaced with a new two-phase inspection system. The party says all schools will be subject to regular ‘health checks’ by councils, with a more in-depth inspection led by Her Majesty’s Inspectors concerns arise. . Labour will have no controls on immigrationWHAT HE SAID: Go with Labour and a totally uncontrolled and unlimited immigration system that would put huge pressure on the NHS and other services. THE FACTS: This relates to a motion that members passed at the party conference, not a manesto pledge. However, even that motion didnapost vow to scrapallcontrols - it pledged to extend free movement and reject any immigration system based on incomes, migrants’ utility to business, and number caps targets. While this is of course a big reduction in controls, it wonapost necessarily become Labour policy going into the election as that is decided by scores of party chiefs in a aposClause Vapos manesto approval meeting. WHAT HE SAID: Corbyn would spend the whole of  having two referendums. One on Scotland – because he has done a deal with the Scots nationalists to assist the break up of the unionthey sustain him in power. THE FACTS: Labour recently ruled out allowing a Scottish independence referendum in . A spokesman said: In the early years, in the formative years of a Labour government, we wouldn’t agree to such a request. But in the longer runthere was a democratic and properly formulated request on the basis of a majority of the Scottish Parliament or the Scottish Government it would be wrong to block it. The door was apparently left open for .

title: should not vote conservative 24
story: NewsWhy should I not vote Conservative   awful policies you cant forget in the  general electionBoris Johnson and his Tory pals are trying to convince you they are on your side before December  - here are some things from the last nine years they hope you forgetShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan BloomOliver Milne:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsBoris Johnson likes to blame everyone  - here is a list of things he, and his party, are responsible for "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson basically wants this election to be about Brexit.According to our floppy haired PM, Brexit is the biggest issue going, and as soon as we all do whatever he wants us to do the quicker the country can head for sunlit uplands.Except that isnapost how elections work.Rather than just being about one thing, it is the one chance we all get to express our judgement on the Government.It has been nine years since the Tories first came to power.Theyaposve been through three Prime Minsters - and the cost of the swingeing cuts theyaposve chosen to make can be seen in every High St up and down this country.So here are just some of the things they want you to forget theyaposve done ahead of election day.   . Promising to build , Starter Homes and building zero In , Conservative Party manesto committed to “, Starter Homes, which will be sold at a % discount and will be built exclusively for first-time buyers under the age of ”. The  Spending Review subsequently provided £. billion to support the delivery of , Starter Homes So how many of the promised homes have been built I hear you ask     None, not one. And according to the National Audit Office, the Tory government paid £million for sites which it then didnapost build any houses on. John Healey, Labouraposs shadow housing secretary, said the Conservative Party had wasted four years and spent millions of pounds. . They spent £, to mislead people about Universal CreditThe DWP published a series of adverts they claimed outlined “myths” about Universal Credit alongside information they claimed was the truth.And they spent £, of taxpayeraposs cash to do it - taking out space in thenewspaper. But an investigation by the Advertising Standards Authority found the ads breached the advertising code  times. In a scathing ruling, the Advertising Standards Authority said a boast that UC “works” because claimants move into work faster was unsubstantiated, exaggerating and misleading.    For their part the DWP say they considering whether to ask for a review of the decision. A DWP spokesman said: We are disappointed with this decision and have responded to the ASA. “We consulted atwith the ASA as we created the adverts, which have explained to hundreds of thousands of people how Universal Credit is helping more than . million people across the country. . They botched privatising probation - and then had to pay to fix it The government was forced to take the supervision of offenders in England and Wales back in-house after a five-year part-privatisation project ended in failure. Low and medium-risk cases had been handled by private probation firms since , but were handed back to the public National Probation Servicein .    The reforms were found to have led to skyrocketing numbers of released offenders ing to prison for breaching their licence conditions after serving short sentences. The Government was forced to spend £ million to scrap contracts with a string of private probation firms in . Sir Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office , said the government set itself up to fail in how it approached the reforms. . They failed to investigate Islamophobia in their own party In May this year, the Muslim Council of Britain wrote to the Equality and Human Rights Commission demanding they investigate hostility to Muslims in the Tory Party. They cited evidence of Islamophobia amongst Members of Parliament, an atmosphere of hostility against Muslim Conservative Party member and the scale of Islamophobia in the party.During the partyaposs leadership contest Sajid Javid bounced the other leadership candidates into holding an inquiry into the issue.But nothing has happened.   Michael Gove , just days before the election said: We will have an independent inquiry into Islamophobia and it will be established before the end of the year.But Boris Johnson has been clear it won’t just be about Islamophobia, and will instead be a broader look at lots of dferen prejudice. Critics say this waters it down. Months after the scandal was brought to light the Tories havenapost done much to investigate the allegations of systemic Islamophobia. Party chiefs have also repeatedly refused to reveal how many members they had suspended over alleged Islamophobia, despite a string of cases being reported to the party. . Slashed police numbers by over , According to Home Office figures, the number of police officers dropped from just under , in  to , in .Now Boris Johnson has said heaposll recruit an extra , police officers in England and Wales.If that happens - which isnapost guaranteed - all it would do is partially reverse cuts that the Tories are responsible for. . Tried to sign ferry contracts with a company that didnapost own any ferries The Tories signed acontract for post-Brexit ferries, with a company that didnapost own any ferries. Seaborne Freightaposs £.m deal fell apart after the firm was mocked for lacking ships and apparently copying terms and conditions from a takeaway website. Kentaposs Port of Ramsgate, where the services to Ostend were meant to depart, wasnapost even ready for the non-existent ships.  Then Transport Secretary and all-around Ministerial failure Chris Grayling swung fully behind the firm, claiming the deal was no problem because itaposs a new start-up business and the contract was tightly-drawn-up. Weeks later, the Department for Transport admitted: It became clear Seaborne would not reach its contractual requirements with the Government. Money was blown on government lawyers drawing up the contract. . Left grieving families without bereavement benefits People who lose their partner before pension age can claim a Bereavement Support Payment - worth up to £,, plus £ a month for  months. But couples must be married or in a civil partnership to qualy - which deprives the benefit to , cohabiting couples with children each year.  They won a victory in August , when the Supreme Court ruled the situation was incompatible with human rights law. But  months later - the situation hasnapost improved leaving thousands of people in desperate situations after the loss of a loved one. Bereavement Support Payments launched in  as a fair replacement for the old system but have been slammed for hitting thousands of families with cuts. That is because while % were estimated to be better off than under the old system, % were worse off. The DWP said MPs had already fully debated whether to allow unmarried couples to claim when the benefit was approved. A DWP spokesman said: “We are committed to supporting people during bereavement and with the introduction of Bereavement Support Payment in April , have widened the support available. This is, in addition, to help provided for co-habiting couples through the wider welfare system. . Universal Credit led to people selling sex to survive The Toriesapos flagship benefit change Universal Credit led to women selling sex in order to survive, according to MPs. A number of women told the work and pensions committee they turned to sex work because their benefits payments did not cover their basic needs. The Work and Pensions Select Committee said problems with the system, including a five-week wait for the first payment, left some women to rely on sex work.  A DWP spokesperson said it was committed to providing a safety net for the most vulnerable in society and had made improvements to universal credit, including extending advance payments, removing waiting days and allowing claimants to continue to be paid housing benefit for two weeks after moving on to universal credit. . They abandoned women hit by rise in the state pension age From November  women in the UK began to qualy for their state pensions at the same age as men - currently . That threshold will go up to  by , and to  by . But women born in the s claim the rise is unfair because they were not given enough time to make adjustments to cope with years without a state pension. The High Court disagreed and ruled in the governmentaposs favour.    But in July, Mr Johnson had promised toto this issue with fresh vigour and new eyes and see what I can do to sort it out. But since he was elected Tory leader he has not offered any new help to the women, In fact, he has only said that we are indeed looking at what more we can do to satisfy that issue . The benefit change that affected almost , children The Toriesapos two-child limit on benefits pushed millions of children deeper into poverty and meant , children went unsupported according to experts. Pioneered by welfare-slashing former Chancellor George Osborne, the limit prevents parents claiming Child Tax Credits or Universal Credit for third or subsequent children born after  April  - a cut of up to £, per child. That forces families to share the same budget they had for two children among three, four or more. Official figures show most families affected are already in work, making a mockery of Tory claims that the change is to encourage people into the job market.    In June, a study by the Child Poverty Action Group found those affected felt strongly that the two-child limit unfairly punished hard-working low-income families at a time – the birth of a child – when they most needed support. They claimed it would push an additional , children into poverty by , while  million children already below the breadline will be pushed into deeper hardship. Speaking at the time a government spokesman said: “This policy helps to ensure fairness by asking parents receiving benefits to face the same financial choices as those in work. Safeguards are in place and we’ve made changes this year to make the policy fairer.” In its final report before the election, the Commons Work and Pensions select committee said it said the two-child cap should be scrapped. . Tried to make it harder to get justice in Employment tribunals In  the government introduced new fees of up to £, for launching tribunals against rogue bosses - in a drive to resolve issues more quickly, outside the court system. But an impact review showed there had been a % drop in the number of cases since they were introduced.    Low-paid women, especially those treated unfairly when they were pregnant or on maternity leave, were the biggest losers, an analysis by Unison found. Finally, in July  the Supreme Court ruled the fees were unlawful, forcing the government to repay £million to around ,. Top judges ridiculed the government’s misunderstanding of “elementary economics, and plain common sense”. . Massive hikes to tuition fees University tuition fees were raised from a maximum of £, a year to £, under the Tory-Lib Dem Coalition. Since then they have been raised again after universities won permission to lt the £, cap with inflation. And reports suggest the Tory manesto does not include a pledge to cut fees . Failed to invest in public health - leading to a reported , preventable deaths According to the IPPR , deaths intEngland since  could have been preventedpublic health policy had not stalled as a direct result of cuts. The think tank claimed that had progress continued at pre  levals that around , lives could have been saved.    IPPRaposs Dean Hochlaf said in June: “We have seen progress in reducing preventable disease flatline since . At the same time, local authorities have seen signicant cuts to their public health budgets, which has severely impacted the capacity of preventative services. “Social conditions for many have failed to improve since the economic crisis, creating a perfect storm that encourages harmful health behaviours. This health challenge will only continue to worsen.” . Made rape victims prove their ordeal A rule grimly nicknamed the rape clause was introduced in April  as part of cuts to tax credits. As weaposve mentioned, claimants can now only be paid tax credits for their first two children, with exceptions for twins or children born of rape. So raped mums must fill out an -page government form in order to claim benefit for their child. Earlier this year the Work and Pensions SecretaryAmber Rudd said: Iaposve been through the form myself and talked to the department about whether weaposve got it right. I believe we have. The form requires a third party, probably Womenaposs Aid or Refuge, to join with the woman who is filling in the form. But otherwise apart from that itaposs almost a self-declaration. . Scrapped nursesapos bursaries In his  spending review, George Osborne unveiled “disastrous” plans to scrap £,-a-year grants for student nurses and midwives. It was supposedly done to allow more training places to open up. But hours after the policy was announced, unions warned us it could prompt a recruitment crisis.  Figures from February  showed that applications had dropped by %. The RCN has warned that the NHS Long Term Plan won’t have a chance to succeedthe decline in student nurse applications isn’t reversed The College urged the Government to invest at least £bn a year in nurse higher education in England to overturn the trend. . Tried to bring back fox hunting As one of his first acts after winning an outright majority in , David Cameron tried to weaken the Hunting Act.The law banning fox hunting was introduced under Labour and has huge public support, according to polls.But ex-PM Mr Cameron wanted to weaken it so an unlimited number of dogs, not just two, could flush a fox from undergrowth.  Activists said that would render the law almost useless, becausehounds rip apart a fox it can be called an accident.In the end the vote was ditched after the SNP went against convention to oppose it .. Cracked down on trade unions standing up for things like not dying at work Passed in summer  after a bitter battle, the Trade Union Act was a wide-ranging crackdown on workersapos rights. It banned strikes unless % of all union members eligible to vote choose them - not % of those who vote, as before.This meant the threshold to strike is now much higher than the threshold to run the country after a general election.The law will also strangle funding to Labour by making union members aposopt-inapos to political donations.Slamming the changes to political funds, Jeremy Corbyn accused the Tories of trying to create a “Zombie democracy” built around a “one-party state”.. Slashed green subsidies In  the Tories slashed funding for small household solar  by %. A £m drop in aposfeed-in tarfsapos was confirmed after critics said the scheme had benefited middle-class families. But Labouraposs shadow energy secretary Lisa Nandy said the cuts would cost jobs, hold back a growing industry and undermine progress on climate change.  New onshore wind farms were also excluded from a subsidy scheme from . And the sell-off of the Green Investment Bank was announced in April , prompting fears from the Lib Dems and Green Party that its help for the environment could be weakened. . Tried to impose fees for court cases More than  magistrates quit in disgust at court fees which led to accusations the Tories were trying to force poorer criminals to plead guilty. They hit small-time criminals of flat fees of up to £, - on top of any fines or compensation - which were five times lowerthey pleaded guilty. The fees were introduced in  and were eventually scrapped just a few months later after outrage across the Justice system. . Cut inheritance tax for the rich The Conservatives won the  election promising to fix the roof while the sun is shining. But there was one way they were happy to loosen the purse strings - inheritance tax.  One of George Osborneaposs first acts when he ed as Chancellor was to let couples leave £, more in property after they die . That means a total of £million can now be left inheritance-tax-free, benefiting just , families, according to estimates. The move was set to cost nearly £billion a year, cash Labour says should be spent on schools and hospitals.. Gutted school fundingFour out of five state schools will be worse off next year according to teaching unions. The Tories claim theyaposll invest £billion in schools over the next three years, but the unions in the School Cuts coalitions say there will still be a shortfall of £.billion compared to  levels. That means more schools closing early, cutting classes and reducing the number of teaching hours. Kevin Courtney, the National Education Union general secretary said in Seprember: “Johnson has made lots of empty promises on school funding – but his numbers don’t add up. The latest funding announcement falls well short of settling the shortfall for every child. And crucially it fails to reverse the cuts schools have suffered since .” . Introduced the Benefit Cap As part of a bid to slash welfare spending, the Tories introduced the Benefit Cap, a cash limit on the amount of support a person could recieve,Launched in , the cap - £, in London and £, outside - has been blamed for social cleansing of inner-city areas. The idea was that it would always pay to work.Except not everyone can go out to work - because of poor health or caring responsibilities.MPs have begged the government to apply it only to those expected to look for work.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The garish striped socks peeking from the small gap between Sir Lindsay Hoyle’s shiny shoes and suit trousers are a flash of colour, and a reminder of tragic sadness. The new Speaker of the House of Commons’ daughter, Natalie, regularly gave him vividly coloured pairs as birthday and Christmas gts.But she took her own le aged just , during what was described at the inquest as a “toxic relationship”. “Natalie used to buy me bright socks,” Sir Lindsay says, looking down at his ankles. “The rest of the family started now she’s gone. “She also gave us a sparkly pink collar for Betty, our Patterdale terrier. I wasn’t going to take her out in that – and then [Natalie] died and we wouldn’t take her for a walk in anything .”    That this Speaker’s gaudy socks have become as much of a trademark as predecessor John Bercow’s lurid ties, is a touching tribute to the child cruelly snatched from him in . Elected by MPs on Monday as First Commoner of the Land – Westminster’s th Speaker – his vulnerability shows even the most successful politicians, are real people who feel pain. “It’s hard, even hard now,” the -year-old MP for Chorley, Lancashire, admits, swallowing to suppress his emotions. “Natalie was a light so bright – I could never have expected what happened. “I’ll never get over it. I need to deal with it but it’s unbearable never to get a call saying, ‘Pops, what you doing ’ “It’s not right. We lost a daughter, my other daughter a sister and my grandchildren lost an auntie.”  Inside the imposing state rooms of Speaker’s House – the living quarters that come with the job – he admits conversations with other MPs who have lost children help him cope. “It won’t get better but it gets easier, they told me,” he says before his voice trails away.The most avuncular MP in Westminster, twice-married Sir Lindsay is the son of Doug Hoyle, a former Warrington MP now Labour peer, who watched him being dragged to the chair in a piece of archaic Parliamentary pantomime. He will have to get used to being a TV star, shouting “Order” during Prime Minister’s Questions.Yet despite being a straight talker in his  years as Bercow’s senior deputy, Sir Lindsay admits he finds it dficult to speak openly about how his feelings. “It’s hard, especially for Lancastrian lads who don’t like to talk publicly.”  Sir Lindsay describes Westminster as a village even though its , pass holders make it a sizeable town. And he will introduce a part-time GP’s surgery so everybody from security staff to lords can receive medical care on site. “We’ve a hairdresser’s but not a doctor – that can’t be right and I’m not against hairdressing,” he says. Having spent a decade chairing debates without pushing his own politics, he won’t say how he voted in the Europe referendum, this political veteran is less abrasive than Bercow. And he is keen to embrace tradition by bringing back the wig and buckled shoes worn for centuries on state occasions before Bercow dropped them. “When I was mayor of Chorley, the things they made me put on mean they’ll hold no fears for me,” he says. Sir Lindsay ran a company printing logos on police and ambulance unorms before winning his seat from the Tories in Tony Blair ’s  landslide.He would clash with Blair on university tuition fees and had a populist eye, once calling for Heathrow to be renamed in memory of Diana Princess of Wales. At heart, though, he was and still is a trade union activist, admired for treating the most junior staff with respect. Asked what makes him angry, the reply is immediate and clear. “I don’t like bullies and injustice.” Recalling an incident when a tearful waitress in the Commons tea room approached him about being poorly treated by a female MP, he says: “She came up to me really upset. “‘Mr Hoyle’ she said, can I have a word with you’. ‘Of course’, I said.  “She told me, nearly in tears, nobody had spoken to her like that before. “I promised it would be dealt with and I went to see the chief whip and it was. There’s no excuse for bullying. I don’t care what caused it. Whatever it was doesn’t make it acceptable. “Every member of staff is as important to me as the Clerk of the House. “I was touched they had come to see me and they can, any time. I suppose it’s the old trade unionist in me, standing up for what’s right and against wrong.” Being named after Australian cricketer Lindsay Hassett, from the “Invincibles” who whitewashed England in , helped, he chuckles, make him stronger. “When you go to school with farmers’ sons called John and Steven it doesn’t half toughen you up to be called Lindsay. “I was the boy called Sue of the song. You don’t know the stick I’ve had. “I still get mistaken for a woman. I’ll go to a hotel and say I’ve got a room booked and they’re expecting a woman.”  The mistakes continued when Sir Lindsay was elected, with his inclusion on a banner made by women in politics campaign group Emily’s List and an invite to join the Labour women’s group. “I was asked to contribute to a book to support the fight against breast cancer but they didn’t use the photo I sent.” As a lad he was sent to the Bolton private secondary school his mum had attended and “absolutely hated it”. “I wanted to be with my friends,” he says If I had my time over, never again.” Through it all the Labour party has been a lelong passion so leaving – Speakers are have to demonstrate independence – was “a toughie”, he admits. “I went to my first Labour conference in  as a baby and soon after, in Scarborough, I was throwing bacon from the high chair at Hugh Gaitskell. I was an early rebel. “I still don’t accept I’ve resigned. The membership card’s in my pocket. I haven’t chopped it up.”

title: 11 times queen wore fur
story: News times The Queen wore fur before agreeing to ban it from her wardrobeHer Majesty has sported fur on many occasions during her reign, however she has now ditched the controversial materialShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  NOV NewsThe Queens decision to ditch fur delighted animal rights activists "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShe may be  but the Queen has proved she’s not set in her ways by taking the modern decision to go fur-free. After decades of real fur coats, Her Maj thrilled animal rights campaigners with the decision to switch to faux-fur in any new outfits, as we reported in yesterday’s Mirror. Her official dresser Angela Kelly revealed the move in her memoir, The Other Side of the Coin: The Queen, the Dresser and the Wardrobe, and said mink trim had been removed from a favourite coat. Buckingham Palace confirmed the news, though the monarch may still wear old fur on existing outfits including ceremonial robes. Here, we look back at Liz’s fur fashions. Coronation robes,   The Queen won’t be able to trim the fur from historic regal robes as she has done with her personal coat. Here, she stands with her six maids of honour and Mistress of the Robes at her coronation at Westminster Abbey in London on June , . The gown is embellished with a crimson velvet mantle edged with ermine. Not surprisingly, she needed a string of maids to help her take the strain. Commonwealth tour,   The Queen and Prince Philip were on their travels with  dresses in tow plus this snowy white stole, a lasting favourite. Here, the stole gets a glamorous outing in Australia, as Elizabeth leaves a banquet with her young husband. Sandown Park,   In , Her Majesty rang the changes and wore a striking leopard-print coat to a Sandown Park race meeting. London Underground,   Her Maj wore this glossy brown fur number for the official opening of the Victoria Line. It is possibly the most expensive coat ever to grace the Underground’s seats. New Zealand,   Outlandish anywhere  – but this traditional Maori cloak was the perfect look for her Jubilee Tour of New Zealand in . Tour of Canada   You wouldn’t want to be standing behind Her Maj on this occasion, wearing a bushy fur hat during her tour of Canada. Dinner with the Duke, London,   Choosing a jauntier, shorter fur jacket than usual, the Queen attends a dinner in Grosvenor Square with the Duke of Edinburgh. State opening of Parliament,   The Queen likes to keep warm for the State Opening of Parliament at the Palace of Westminster and has often teamed this extravagant thick fur with the George IV State Diadem. Welsh Assembly, Cardf,   The Queen chose an orange coat and matching hat with brown fur trim for the official opening of the Welsh National Assembly building in Cardf Bay. Armistice Day,   Have the fur collar and pom-pom been dyed green or was this an early foray into fake fur  On Armistice Day in , The Queen and Maori Warrant Officer Wal Wallace attended the official dedication of the New Zealand Memorial at Hyde Park Corner. Christmas Day,   Her Maj arrives in good spirits for the traditional Christmas Day church service at Sandringham in  in a Russian-style fur hat and matching cuffs.

The respected online edition also named “climate strike” as its word of the year for . It follows pop star Sam Smith coming out as non-binary and -year-old Greta Thunberg launching a global environmental movement. Bosses said “non-binary” was now part of the English lexicon and it recognised “changes in how people relate to each other and define themselves”. A person who identies as non-binary does not define themselves exclusively as masculine or feminine. They often prefer they them pronouns, rather than he she.

title: girl who sent birthday card
story: NewsGirl who sent birthday card to dad in heaven delighted as it arrives safelyLittle Hollie Morgan wrote to her army veteran dad, Nigel Morgan, who died in after being struck by bronchial pneumonia - and was delighted to receive a surprise replyShareCommentsByPaul Byrne:,  NOV NewsA letter to heaven... "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little girl who sent a birthday card to her dad “in heaven” was overjoyed to learn it had been successfully delivered. Hollie Morgan, six, posted the handmade card to her dad Nigel to mark his th birthday after his death last year. And days later she was told her message had been safely delivered after “avoiding stars and other galactic objects en route to heaven”. Hollie’s mum Laura Allen, , said: “We’d heard about people doing similar sorts of things and though we’d give it a go. “She wanted to wish her dad a happy birthday as he would have been  in October.  “She wrote it out and put ‘to dad in heaven’ on the envelope before we took it to the post office. “The postmaster said it needed a special stamp on because it was going to heaven and told Hollie that she needed to write her address on the back. “He said they would write to her to let it know it had arrived safely.” Hollie then received a letter from Royal Mail confirming her letter had been successfully sent to heaven.  Laura, from Widnes, Cheshire, said: “I got the post through the letter box and one of the letters had Hollie’s name on so I wasn’t sure what it was at first. “She opened it and asked me to read it. She was so happy about it. It was wonderful. “Despite her age she understands what’s happened and is very resilient about it all. “She always talks about her dad and the things they did together and the games they played with each other.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle dressed all in dark blue as she arrived to meet D-Day veterans at Westminster Abbey’s Field of Remembrance this morning. The Duke and Duchess were due to attend the event with Camilla Parker-Bowles in what would have been their first joint engagement together. However, shortly before her scheduled arrival the Duchess of Cornwall announced she could not attend because of a chest infection. Shortly before am the Duke and Duchess of Sussex arrived at the st Field of Remembrance at the central London place of worship.    It was the seventh time His Royal Highness has attended the event but the first time for The Duchess of Sussex. The Royals met veterans from all areas of the Armed Forces who have served in past campaigns and more recent conflicts. Amongst those in line to meet the Duke and Duchess were  D-Day veterans.  The Exhortation to Remembrance was spoken by Surgeon Rear Admiral Lionel Jarvis, president of the Poppy Factory, who said: They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old. Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning we will remember them. The Field of Remembrance has been organised by The Poppy Factory and held in the grounds of Westminster Abbey since November , when only two Remembrance Tribute Crosses were planted. There are now approximately , crosses produced by the Factory team each year which are planted on more than  plots for regimental and other associations.    Ex-service men and women, as well as members of the public, can plant a cross carrying a personal message in memory of those who have lost their lives in the service of others. The Field is opened every Thursday before Remembrance Sunday and runs for ten days. The royals each laid a Cross of Remembrance while the ‘Last Post’ was played.    A two minute silence and reveille then followed the chimes of Big Ben. Speaking about Camillaaposs absence, a Clarence House spokeswoman said: The Duchess of Cornwall has been told by her doctor to cancel her engagements owing to a chest infection which has got progressively worse over the last few days. Camilla also missed an event last night in London due to the infection.    Yesterday Harry and Meghan surprised military families when they dropped in on a coffee morning at Broom Farm Community Centre in Windsor. They took the time to talk with families from the Welsh Guards, Coldstream Guards and Household Cavalry about what army le is really like. The majority of the Coldstream Guards are on exercise in Kenya, while a large proportion of the Welsh Guards are coming to the end of a long deployment to The Falklands.

title: lotto winners joy becoming grandparents
story: NewsEuroMillions winners become grandparents after paying for daughters IVF babyEXCLUSIVE: Mark, , and Ruth Chalmers, , from Halax, say welcoming grandchild Koby is “better than winning the lottery” after watching helplessly for years as daughter Natalie, , struggled to conceiveShareCommentsByLucy Thornton:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsProud grandparents Mark and Ruth Chalmers with youngster Koby "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn “ecstatic” couple have revealed how their £million lottery win “made their lives” after it helped them become grandparents. Mark, , and Ruth Chalmers, , used some of their winnings to fund their daughter Natalie’s IVF treatment after she had tried for six years to conceive. Their daughter had “given up hope” of becoming a mum after suffering fertility problems and enduring five operations. The “devastated” -year-old was unable to get IVF on the NHS as her partner, Nigel Armitage, , had children. But her dreams came true after her parents scooped £million in the EuroMillions raffle in February .  Today, Mr and Mrs ­Chalmers, of Halax, West Yorks, said their first grandchild was “better than winning the lottery”. The first decision they made after their win was to fund her £, IVF treatment. Two months later she was pregnant after her first attempt and on December  last year Koby was born. Ruth, a former wages clerk at Tesco, said. “I never thought I’d have a grandchild. It was heartbreaking to watch what Natalie went through for six years. I’ve seen her in tears and in pain.  “If I could have done, I’d have had one for her, but it wasn’t possible. I thought it was so unfair that because of where she lived she couldn’t get IVF on the NHS. I never thought the day would come I’d be able to take that pain away.” Ruth remembers the call that changed her le, saying: “I was in China with my niece on holiday and Natalie called to say, ‘I can’t believe it, the first time and it’s worked – you’re going to be a grandma’. We both burst into tears.” Dad Mark said Natalie couldn’t stop crying when she called him. He said: “In between tears I heard, ‘I’m pregnant’. I asked her, ‘Why the hell are you crying ’.”  Mark had just taken early retirement after  years with Mars when he won. They were planning to take money out of his own pension to pay for IVF. Natalie, who suffers from polycystic oy syndrome, said she was distraught after doctors had told her she may need to have her tubes removed. “The lottery has made all our lives. I’m so happy,” Natalie said. “I had about five operations. They made holes in my oies to seethat helped.  “I thought I’d never have children. So when it happened I was in total shock. It didn’t really sink in until he was born and then I cried and thought, ‘he’s mine’.” Mark told how he believes winning the lottery is “fate” and revealed he left his ticket in his wallet for about a month before he checked it. He works as a landscape gardener three days a week with his brother and Ruth cares for her grandson.

Simon Goldsmith, , was told he was “too comical” for the annual King’s Crown Elvis contest and would be “laughed off stage”. The postman, who raises money for charity by performing in his white sequin suit, insists he has been treated unfairly. Simon said: “I might look a bit rubbish, but I can sing and put on a really good show. “I just want to do something dferent and to be fun. “You see a lot of Elvis tributes who just go through all his tracks but I do something dferent.    “When I saw the quality of some [of the acts that] got in I thought ‘I could have done that’.” Simon, who admits he is probably Britain’s worst Elvis tribute, describes his act as “quite slapstick”. He covers modern songs by artists including Britney Spears in Elvis style,and also dresses as ‘Zombie Elvis’. Simon was hoping to donate the £ prize from last month’s competition in Ipswich, Suffolk, to a hospice in memory of his dad.    But after his application was turned down he decided to raise funds himself, making £ in just three days. Andy Sexton, the organiser of the King’s Crown Elvis competition, says he admires Simon’s charity work but stands by his decision. He said: “Our Elvis competition is not a comedy show “These guys are professionals. I choose between  to  to enter and they have to be the best.

She was greeted with cheers and shouts of God Save the Queen as she arrived at the Royal British Legionaposs Centenary Village in Aylesford to tour the facilities, which support members of the Armed Forces. But many fans were surprised to see she wasnapost wearing a poppy for the visit. She looked beautul in a dark purple coat and hat, which she teamed with a stunning diamond brooch. The Queen simply doesnapost wear her poppy before the Remembrance weekend, and she will have it on when she arrives at the Royal Albert Hall on Saturday.She will be joined by Prince Charles, Camilla, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, Meghan Markle , Prince Harry and other members of the Royal Family for the Festival of Remembrance.   On Sunday the same group will attend the Remembrance Sunday service at The Cenotaph. The Queen will watch from the balcony while Charles lays a wreath on her behalf. During her visit to the centre today, the Queen also had a minor run-in with a guide dog, which appeared entirely unfazed as it blocked her path during her visit. Smiling, she quipped: Heaposs bored of this, I think. The Queen took her time speaking to dozens of people, listening to their stories of service for the country all over the world and in numerous dferent conflicts.    The village houses specialist accommodation for armed forces personnel and veterans and their families, as well as those with a disability and the long-term unemployed. The new Appleton Lodge is the latest part of the £ million Centenary Village development which, when complete, will provide homes and welfare support, as well as a community for vulnerable veterans. RBLI, which was formed in  to provide support to sick and wounded soldiers ing from the First World War, launched a campaign in  to build the Centenary Village, which the charity says will see it support hundreds of the most in-need ex-servicemen and women every year for another century. At every turn, the Queen was met with beaming smiles from the hundreds of schoolchildren, veterans, families and staff gathered at the village. Among those eager to meet the royal was Irene Mount, who was born in the same year as the Queen and was one of the first residents to move into the new Appleton Lodge.    The Queen said to her: You have got a nice place here, havenapost you. And they look after you well  Mrs Mount, , sitting next to her son, said she was happy at the lodge. Her husband Reginald Mount had served as Chief Petty Officer in the Royal Navy in the Fleet Air Arm and died  years ago. Turning to Mrs Mount before she left, the Queen said: I am very glad to see you today. After touring the facility, the royal was invited to unveil a plaque to officially open Appleton Lodge, which she did to cheers from the crowd. Elsewhere on the Centenary Village site, the Queen was treated to a tour of Victory House, another set of apartments for veterans. There she met Fijian-born John Ahben, who served with the Kingaposs Own Royal Border Regiment before he was involved in a car accident.    Mr Ahben, who was unconscious for more than two weeks after the incident, stayed at rehabilitation centre Headley Court several times before he joined the RBLI in . He now works as a horticulturist, tending the Cha Garden which he showed to the Queen. The Queen also met members of Britainaposs Bravest Manufacturing Company, an enterprise run by the RBLI which employs veterans and people with disabilities. The factory employs over  people,  of whom are veterans, have a health condition or both. Brigadier Steve Sherry, RBLI chief executive, said: One hundred years ago, a group of philanthropists and forward thinkers came together to set up a community encompassing homes, welfare and employment to support vulnerable veterans. Weaposre immensely proud to still be doing this today.

story: NewsWoman lost st because she didnt want to be known as husbands fat weSonia Greensill, a mum of two, weight st and was too ashamed to meet new people because of her size and says she felt abnormalShareCommentsByDawn Collinson:,  NOV NewsWeighing more than st Sonia was too ashamed to meet new people "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhenever her husband planned a night out with work friends, Sonia Greensill always found an excuse not to go. Weighing more than  stone, she was too ashamed to meet new people. I didn’t want to be an embarrassment to my husband, or to anyone really, she says. I used to think,they meet me then they’ll know he’s married to a fat woman. I didn’t want to be the one that people saw and thought, oh god, look at the size of her. So I’d find a reason not to go, because then I didn’t have to face it. I missed out on so much because of that, but still it wasn’t enough to stop me eating all the wrong things. I really wish it had been.    Sonia, who has two grown-up children and two grandchildren, was approaching her th birthday and weighing st lb when she decided it was time to change her le. I realised I was at the age where it was now or never, she remembers. I thoughtI didn’t do it then it would be too late. It wasn’t just about being slim, I didn’t want to stand out anymore, I wanted to be unnoticeable. Being so big, I honestly felt abnormal and I just wanted to feel normal. I felt judged all the time, and I couldn’t really argue with it. I was fat and I’d made myself that way so people had every reason to be judgemental, but it was still a horrible feeling.”    When Sonia’s daughter Sharn suggested they go to Slimming World together, she initially refused. “My daughter had put on four stones when she was about , then joined Slimming World and lost it, but put a couple back on so she thought it would be a good ideawe both went,” says Sonia. “But when she first asked me I said ‘I’m not going there, no chance.’ I hadn’t stood on the scales for years, my attitude wasI didn’t know then I didn’t have to think about it. But I started thinking maybe my daughter was worried about me, and should I be worrying about me too ” Sonia’s weigh first started to creep up in her teens – “when everyone was getting a figure, mine just kind of exploded!” she jokes. “I met my husband Colin when I was  and started eating at his house, having curries and things I’d never really eaten at home. It was this new world of food and I couldn’t get enough of it.” Rather than over-eating, Sonia says she ate the wrong types of food.    Butter was my real weakness. I’d lash it on thick white bread toast in the mornings, or on a bacon sandwich, then on a couple of crusty cobs at lunchtime. I just loved it. As the weigh piled on, Sonia found it more and more dficult to indulge her passion for fashion, despite working at Evans plus-size clothes chain at the time. I went up to a size  so I was really limited to what I could wear – everything was stretchy and elasticated or loose-fitting. I absolutely love clothes, but I became a bit mumsy and just faded into the background. It bothered me but I never said it, I just concentrated on being the best mum I could be and I think I dressed my teenage daughter how I would have loved to dressI could.” Sonia, who lives in Cannock, Staffordshire, says she never shared her feelings about her weigh with anyone and her family never mentioned it.  “My husband just loved me for how I was, whatever size I was, and I’m grateful for that but sometimes I wish he’d turned said ‘you could really do with doing something about your size’ even though I don’t know how I’d have reacted. Since I’ve lost weight he’s told me he’d often hear people snigger or make comments, but he didn’t tell me then because he didn’t want to upset me. With walking even short distances starting to become impossible, Sonia, joined her local Slimming World group in February . “I actually didn’t find it that hard to stick to the meal plans because it was basically the same food, but just cooked in a much healthier way,” she says.  “My mindset totally changed. I thought I loved toast with loads of butter so I never gave anything  a chance, but now I love fresh fruit for breakfast and I’d choose it over toast any day. “I’ll have fruit every morning, or grilled bacon with poached egg and mushrooms at weekends, then I’ll make my own soups for lunch in the winter, and have something like Cajun chicken with salad and veg or pasta for dinner. It’s all the food I like so I’m having it because I enjoy it, not because I’ve got to.” As the weight fell off, Sonia joined a gym for the first time – “I thought they were places fit people went, not people who wanted to get fit,” she admits – and she now goes running three times a week. She reached her target weight a year ago and is now down to just st lb – a loss of st lb. And the -year-old is finally able to shop where she wants and go where she wants.

story: NewsWhy you should always lt your bag off the floor - and  other le hacksFrom unplugging chargers to leaving your desk at lunch, Michele O’Connor reveals the small le hacks that make a big dferenceShareCommentsByMichele OConnor:,  NOV NewsWatch out for germs!"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhether we realise it or not, we make lots of tiny mistakes each and every day. For example, did you know that % of Brits follow bad practices before bed  Caffeine, booze and use of ­electronic devices are the main offenders, according to a new survey by bed manufacturer Sealy. And of the % of UK adults who have used free public Wi-Fi, more than half have entered passwords and used online banking, leaving them at risk of being hacked. But there is good news – tiny mistakes need just tiny changes to put them right. Here we explore how to correct these common errors... Ban the snooze button  It’s certainly tempting to put the alarm on snooze to grab an extra  minutes. “But by dozing off again, we’re preparing our bodies for another sleep cycle, which is then quickly interrupted – causing us to feel fatigued for the rest of the day,” says Holly Housby, sleep expert at Sealy UK. Unplug your charger Electrical appliances kept plugged in when not in use are a major cause of wasted energy. Phone chargers can cost up to £ a year in unused energy. Wait before mouthwash    “Never swill mouthwash straight after brushing – it just removes the protective fluoride from the toothpaste,” warns Dr Mark Buddha, director at MyClinique Dental. Reduce waste Every year Brits throw away  million eggs and  million pints of milk because of our reliance on best-before dates, according to research by Too Good to Go. Dairy brand Arla is now planning to scrap use-by dates on milk, encouraging customers to snf or taste it instead. You can also try the egg test. A fresh egg will sink to the bottom of a bowl of cold water and lie on its side. Eggs nearing expiration – but still fresh enough to eat – will sink and sit upright. Eggs that aren’t fresh will float. Limit your social sharing Less than half of Brits set their social media profiles to private, says online security firm McAfee. The company’s chief scientist Raj Samani says: “And our research discovered that % of people disclose their location when posting online. Be careful what you post and increase privacy settings to ensure tagged posts are only shared with people you know and trust.”  Lead the way Surgeons warn dog owners not to wrap leads around their fingers or wrist because of the dangers of ­laceration, friction burns, fractures and ligament injuries. Avoid public Wi-Fi    Fake Wi-Fi hotspots allow cybercriminals to ­eavesdrop on users and steal usernames, ­passwords and bank details. They often have innocuous sounding names such as “airport wi-fi” and can redirect victims to malicious malware and phishing sites. Genuine public networks ask the user to agree to the terms and ­conditions of accessing the Wi-Fi so an immediate connection could signal an unsafe connection. Always ensure the web address bar reads HTTPS instead of HTTP and check for a padlock. This means that the data is encrypted. Reduce email time A new study of , office workers found they typically spend around two hours each day browsing their inbox – wasting  work days a year. But each time you stop to read or respond to an email it takes between three and  minutes to get your focus back on to what you were previously doing. Turn off notications and batch-check your emails at allocated times. Lt your bag off the floor There are more germs on the floor of a public toilet than on the toilet seat itself, so hang your bag on the hook in public loos. And clean it regularly with ­disinfectant wipes. Choose dferent passwords Password management company Dashlane analysed more than  million ­passwords and discovered many of us use obvious ones, or “password walk”– making hackers’ jobs very easy. In fact, the most commonly selected password is “”. Leave your desk at lunch  Office workers only manage to take an average of  minutes each day for lunch, according to a recent study. Apart from the obvious benefits of taking a break from sitting, our brain needs time to refresh. Exercise right

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum-of-one was left fighting for her le three times from contracting deadly sepsis following a UTI after brushing her symptoms off as aposmenopausalapos.While taking her mother to hospital for an operation in November , Jessica Middour, , suddenly started profusely sweating and being sick, but instantly dismissed it as a aposhot flashapos and aposnervesapos. However, when the former bank worker became faint she was rushed to the emergency room downstairs in the hospital and was given the diagnosis that she had a urinary tract infection. But her instant relief quickly wore off as Jessica was then told she went into septic shock and began fighting for her le hooked up to two dferent IV lines and enduring brain, liver and kidney scans.    After one week in hospital Jessica ed home and back to work before being struck by the same symptoms again just six months laterand was diagnosed with sepsis again, deriving from another UTI. Jessica then quit her job due to her lack of energy and inability to complete apossimpleapos tasks when she was struck with the deadly infection once more in January . However, after saying goodbye to her family and believing there was no recovering this time, Jessica beat the odds and survived sepsis for the third time. Now, she is sharing her story to encourage people to never brush off their symptoms and to ask doctorsit aposcould be sepsisapos when they are receiving diagnosis. Jessica, from Waynesboro, Pennsylvania, said: I had taken my mother to the hospital to receive surgery when I suddenly came over very hot - but I thought it was just menopausal hot flashes.    Then I was sick, but still I thought it would just be my nerves because of my motheraposs surgery, so continued to just sit down fanning myself and waiting for her to be seen. Her nurse noticed that I was sweating and looking unwell and told me to go to the emergency room downstairs, but I didnapost listen until I tried to stand up and fell straight back down. When I went downstairs I gave urine samples, had all sorts of scans and was hooked up to IV drips - and after a while I was told I had a UTI, which gave me instant relief. However, just hours later they told me I had gone into septic shock and for the next week I was still in the hospital fighting for my le.    When I was finally allowed home I hoped it was all over so I ed back to work - but then six months later the same symptoms came over me like a wave and, when I got to hospital, I was diagnosed with sepsis again. Once again, I battled through this sepsis before being diagnosed with it again under a year later. This time I said goodbye to my family because I was certain that I couldnapost be lucky a third time, but somehow I was. Every time it was as a result of a UTI - something which is so common in so many women.  Hopefully from sharing my story people will realise it can be so much deeper than your initial diagnosis and Iaposm encouraging people to push their doctors to askit could be sepsis. Despite surviving the le-threatening condition three times, Jessica admits that she suffers from apospost-sepsis syndromeapos still to this day. She said: I have had to quit my job because the side effects of having sepsis three times are just too strong. I am constantly tired, I have constant joint pains, Iaposve lost the feeling in my toes and I canapost solve simple problems or tasks like I used to be able to.

The violence has seen vandalism, arson attacks and looting in one of Latin America’s richest nations, where there is also anger at the yawning gap between rich and poor. Police have responded by using tear gas canisters, rubber bullets and water cannons against the protesters. Two police officers were engulfed in flames and helped by colleagues who used fire extinguishers and their hands.    The two women, María José Hernández Torres, , and Abigail Catalina Aburto Cardenas, , both members of the Santiago police special forces, are in serious condition in hospital, police said. Chile’s Interior Minister Gonzalo Blumel visited the pair in hospital on Monday evening and denounced the attack as “pure violence... nothing to do with the legitimate demands of citizens.” He said: “It was a violent, cowardly aggression against two police officers who were working to protect the safety of our compatriots.”    The two women are among  police officers injured in the demonstrations over the last two weeks, along with , protesters who have been hospitalised, according to human rights groups. Meanwhile, a Chilean prosecutor said today he would seek court approval to investigate  police officers for allegedly torturing protesters during the three weeks of intense unrest and rioting in the country. Manual Guerra, the prosecutor for Santiago East, said the investigation was related to two separate cases during a nine-day state of emergency in the capital Santiago from October .    One related to the actions of  police officers in Nunoa, a bohemian suburb of Santiago, where protestors defied a curfew to conduct successive nights of large but mainly peaceful demonstrations in a central square, a spokesman for Guerra told Reuters without providing further details. The second related to two officers in the lower-middle class area of La Florida who were accused of beating a young man who was handcuffed, the spokesman said. The alleged abuses took place against a backdrop of  days of mass rioting, looting and, more recently, peaceful protests over endemic inequality in one of Latin Americaaposs richest nations.
